item.title: From Councilwoman Candi CdeBaca: ￼The Independent Monitor’s...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

From Councilwoman Candi CdeBaca:
￼The Independent Monitor’s devastating report affirms what tens of thousands of protesters already knew: we live in a city where police officers can commit unprecedented human rights violations, turn off their body cameras, remove their name badges, fail to file reports, and never be held accountable by Mayor Hancock’s administration.

There is no other institution where employees can brutalize its people and then get raises; violate its own po...licies and then get millions more for equipment; cause life-shattering injuries, and then blame the victims; use weapons recklessly, but hold no one in leadership accountable.

The Monitor’s report makes clear that deploying so-called “less lethal” weapons when shooting projectiles at people’s heads, faces, and groins increases the risk of harm to everyone involved — and reaffirms what the research already tells us: police respond more violently to anti-police protests than to any other type of First Amendment demonstration.

In light of this troubling report, I hope my City Council colleagues will finally take action to protect the rights of the hundreds of constituents who were harmed by the very people sworn to protect them, and not continue to reward bad behavior. When we are transforming an inherently racist and persistently violent institution, no option should be off the table—including changes in leadership and immediately redirecting a portion of the DPD budget to repairing the harm and rebuilding the public’s trust.

Find ways to take action here: https://www.facebook.com/CandiCdeBaca…/posts/700951807291994

“The watchdog could not paint a full picture of violence because the police department was not fully transparent.

"According to the report, body cameras often remained off. Officers often failed to file use-of-force reports. Many also failed to identify themselves by name or badge number. DPD said it did not document who worked the first four days of the protests. And the OIM found that the department did not effectively track its use of munitions, which would’ve helped officials understand the level of violence....

"Meanwhile, 18 other jurisdictions aided DPD’s response, and some used weapons and tactics that are not approved by DPD.

"After police ran out of munitions on the first night, they received a literal plane-load of new ones. But DPD brass doesn’t know exactly who used them and how they were used.”

item.title: “T he Denver Post requested Brady lists from each of the 22...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

“T he Denver Post requested Brady lists from each of the 22 district attorneys’ offices in Colorado. From the nine offices that provided a list, The Post compiled a list of 466 current and former law enforcement officers with criminal convictions, histories of lying, excessive force incidents or other backgrounds that could impact their credibility in court. The records offer insight into the often-opaque realm of police discipline in Colorado, but because some offices withhe...ld their lists it’s impossible to know how many other officers have a Brady designation, whether they’re still working in law enforcement or whether an officer on a list in one jurisdiction has moved to another.

That means it can be difficult for people to know whether an officer testifying against them in court or issuing a ticket has lied before, or whether the officers entrusted with arresting powers to keep communities safe are trustworthy themselves.”

Great commentary from Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition on Polis's comments attempting to limit prisoners's access to a COVID-19 vaccine:

"The issue on the table isn’t who is more “deserving” to receive the vaccine but, rather, how to deploy the vaccine as strategically as possible to ensure the health of essential workers, to reduce infection in high transmission environments, and to prioritize those individuals most vulnerable due to age or underlying medical cond...ition.

Over 4,300 incarcerated people have tested positive for COVID, which is 30% of the entire adult prison population, and that figure is surging. To put this in context, if the overall state population had an infection rate of 30%, rather than having 236,000 people who have been infected, it would be over 1.3 million."
